screens.headline: Why did you choose THAT strike price?
screens.text: Most beginners pick strikes randomly - 'that one looks good!' - and wonder why they keep losing money. In 7 minutes, you'll learn the systematic approach that professionals use.

screens.headline: Strike Selection = Risk vs Reward
screens.text: Higher strikes give you MORE upside potential but LESS premium income. Lower strikes give you MORE premium income but cap your gains sooner. There's no 'perfect' strike - only the right strike for YOUR goal and risk tolerance.

screens.headline: Think of it like insurance deductibles
screens.text: Low deductible ($500) = High monthly premium but you're covered faster. High deductible ($5,000) = Low monthly premium but you need bigger claims to benefit. Same with covered calls: Out-of-the-money (OTM) strikes = higher profit potential, less premium. At-the-money (ATM) strikes = more premium, lower profit potential.

reveal_sections.label: Low deductible = At-the-money strike (more premium, less upside)
High deductible = Out-of-the-money strike (less premium, more upside)
Monthly premium = Your option premium income
Coverage = Your profit potential before assignment

cards.definition: Strike price equals (or very close to) current stock price
cards.example: Stock $180, sell $180 call = highest premium, immediate cap

cards.definition: Strike price ABOVE current stock price (for calls)
cards.example: Stock $180, sell $190 call = lower premium, room for stock gain

screens.question: Stock is $100. Which strike gives you the MOST premium income?
options: All strikes pay the same premium
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! At-the-money strikes ($100) always have the highest premium because there's maximum time value. But you give up all upside immediately - the stock is already at your strike!
screens.explanation_wrong: The closer the strike is to the current price, the more premium it pays. An ATM $100 strike pays more than a $105 or $110 strike.

screens.question: You own AAPL at $170 (very bullish). Which covered call strategy makes sense?
options: Sell $180 strike (OTM) for less premium but more upside
Don't sell any calls - you're too bullish
screens.explanation_correct: Smart! If you're VERY bullish and expect big gains, don't cap your upside with a covered call. Wait until your bullish thesis plays out, THEN start selling calls. Or sell far OTM strikes ($200+) that won't interfere.
screens.explanation_wrong: Think about your outlook: If you expect AAPL to soar, why would you cap your gains at $170 or even $180? Either skip covered calls or sell so far OTM ($200+) that assignment is unlikely.

screens.headline: Strike Picker Tool
screens.description: Compare three different strike prices for the same stock
teaching_points: Try 'Very Bullish': Far OTM preserves upside
Premium vs Upside is always a trade-off

cards.back: Sell AT-THE-MONEY strikes. Max premium, you don't expect stock to run anyway. Income is the goal.
Sell OUT-OF-THE-MONEY strikes 2-5% above current price. Balanced premium + upside room.
DON'T sell covered calls OR sell FAR OTM (>10% above). Preserve your upside potential.
